posts.name: Joshua Truman
posts.cooked: During a comp, our WAGO terminal for battery wire shorted and melted (same as this post ). We took it apart, thinking we could replace the WAGO terminal, but found it was soldered on. Is this part not replaceable? Is there anything we can do to save this PDH (even if it means we canâ€™t use it in an actual competition)?

posts.name: Roger Moore
posts.cooked:
REV does offer a repair service.

REV Robotics designs, builds and manufactures robotics parts and components used by students for learning about science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM). Our parts are commonly used within the FIRST Robotics Competition and the FIRST Tech...

Price: USD 110

I would suggest contacting REV support to see if the damage can be repaired.

link_counts.title: Power Distribution Hub Repair Service - REV Robotics

posts.name: James Lyon
posts.cooked: The wagon terminals used in the PDPs are made by wago to be soldered on. I think you can buy new terminals from digi-key, but Iâ€™m unsure if it would still be competition legal, considering how much power goes through those ports.

posts.name: Marcus Kauffman
posts.cooked:
Same team as @jt4929 . Based on the photos he sent me, it looks like the wago melted, not the wire insulation. image 944Ã—1071 165 KB image 1536Ã—2048 445 KB

image 944Ã—1071 165 KB

image 944Ã—1071 165 KB

image 1536Ã—2048 445 KB

image 1536Ã—2048 445 KB

Looks like it could be a different issue than the one from the linked post.

If you want to repair it yourself â€“ which is possible, but I will not endorse this path because itâ€™s not the safest most reliable path IMO â€“ the connector used is WAGO 2616-1352 . You could obtain this somehow (itâ€™s not in stock at DigiKey but might be somewhere else), then desolder the existing connections and replace with this. It wonâ€™t have the red and black colors so youâ€™d have to be careful. Under my reading of the game manual this is legal, per R710:

* Only specified modifications to control system devices permitted. The Driver Station Software, roboRIO, PDP /PDP2.0/ PDH , PCM (s)/PH(s), VRM (s)/ RPM (s), RSL , 120A breaker, motor controllers, MXP devices used to control actuators per R713-C, relay modules (per R504-B), wireless bridge, PDP /PDP2.0/ PDH breakers and fuses, Servo Power Module, Servo Hub, Kraken Powerpole adapter boards, and batteries shall not be tampered with, modified, or adjusted in any way (tampering includes drilling, cutting, machining, rewiring, disassembling, painting, etc.), with the following exceptions: â€¦ M. Devices may be repaired, provided the performance and specifications of the device after the repair are identical to those before the repair. â€¦ S. replacing control system power terminal blocks (e.g. RSL power connector) with functional equivalents

However, I could see an inspector not passing this, and I definitely wouldnâ€™t recommend this over the Repair Service that REV offers.

EDIT: It seems to be in stock at https://www.newark.com/wago/2616-1352/terminal-block-wtb-2pos-18-4awg/dp/74AH2820

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked: Itâ€™s also probably going to take a lot of heat to desolder. Good bit of conductor on both rails.

posts.name: Clayton Yocom
posts.cooked: Weâ€™ve repaired one of ours this way (and set aside to be used on practice chassis/demo robots), be warned it does take a beefy soldering iron to be able to handle this amount of copper.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
As others have stated, a high-power soldering iron will be necessary.

If you donâ€™t have a reasonable amount of experience reworking circuit boards, it can be pretty easy to permanently damage the circuit board.
